summary: [[MORE]] Daenerys  by  G-host Lee  The Great Masters had used the pit as a prison. It was large enough to hold five hundred men...
caption:
Daenerys by G-host Lee The Great Masters had used the pit as a prison. It was large enough to hold five hundred men … and more than ample for two dragons. For how long, though? What will happen when they grow too large for the pit? Will they turn on one another with flame and claw? Will they grow wan and weak, with withered flanks and shrunken wings? Will their fires go out before the end? What sort of mother lets her children rot in darkness? If I look back, I am doomed, Dany told herself … -

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: I think a lot of people are taking what Peter Dinklage said about Tyrion to mean that he wants to bang Dany and is jealous of...
body:
I think a lot of people are taking what Peter Dinklage said about Tyrion to mean that he wants to bang Dany and is jealous of Jon, and this will lead to his betrayal, but let’s look again at what Peter actually said:

“It’s complicated. A lot of the time with Tyrion, it’s professional and personal. Obviously, he has feelings for Daenerys. He loves her — or thinks he does. She’s awe-inspiring. He’s questioning that because he doesn’t have a good track record for falling in love. There’s jealousy wrapped up in there. And he loves Jon Snow, too. They’re the two people he has the most in common with, in a way — they’re both outsiders in their own families who have refused to follow the path their family has taken, and hopefully for the better. He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because passion and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.”

There’s a lot to unpack here. First of all:

1. It’s complicated, as are most of Tyrion’s relationships with others. Dinklage says that a lot of the time with Tyrion, it’s professional and personal. We already know that Tyrion has trouble separating these two areas in his relationships, see his relationships with Bronn and Shae, but also Sansa, whom he is not supposed to empathize with on a personal level because she is a Lannister prisoner, but he does. He has conflicting political and personal loyalties when he is still allied with his family against the Starks, and now he’s allied with Dany, working for a regime he actually personally believes in, but he can’t shake the deeply learned loyalty to his family, even despite all they did to him, or because he’s still hoping for their validation.

2. He loves Dany, or thinks he does. On a physical level, Dany is beautiful. She’s awe-inspiring, has already achieved mythical status - in the books dubbed "the most beautiful woman in the world” which has more to do with that mythologizing than her actual appearance - is powerful, has done incredibly things, has woken dragons and freed slaves. Why wouldn’t Tyrion love her? On a more personal level, Dany is a champion of the dispossessed, mother to her people. Tyrion is a dwarf without a mother, why wouldn’t he love her, this mother of dragons, this breaker of chains? And she’s chosen him as her hand, not because of what his name is but because of his own merit. This is the kind of affirmation that Tyrion has longed for, and the scene where she presents him with the hand pin definitely had romantic overtones, as Dany dumped Dario in the exact same scene as she took Tyrion as her Hand. Of course Tyrion is in love with Dany on some level.

3. However, Tyrion “doesn’t have a good track record for falling in love.” His love for Dany is probably something he himself is not sure how to identify. I think with Tyrion, his romantic feelings are gonna be a big mess because saying he doesn’t have a good track record is…putting it mildly. Does he want to have sex with her? Does he want a replacement for the familial love he never got? Does he want affirmation in his skills as an advisor? Does he want her to see him as a hero, the way she now sees Jon, because Jon is big and strong and able bodied and everything Tyrion isn’t? Probably all three. Which leads me to.

4. Jealousy. Which I don’t think is necessarily romantic jealousy, but more relating to Tyrion’s deep rooted insecurities about himself as a man and a person, due to his specific traumas. I think there is romantic jealousy in there, but like I said, it’s all a big mess because Tyrion was never taught how to give or recieve love. The models he has for that are the toxic relationships in his own family, including his family’s abuse of him, his father’s worship of a dead woman, and his brother and sister’s obsessive relationship.

5. Tyrion ALSO loves Jon Snow. He’s probably worried about them both, as Dinklage says, but also: I think Tyrion can’t help feeling the kind of jealousy someone in his position might feel, not necessarily a romantic jealousy but one born from the loneliness of his position. Tyrion is a very lonely person and he longs for the kind of connection he sees in people around him. Here are two people he loves getting together, and he’s left alone, and jealous not necessarily because he thinks Dany should have chosen him, but because these two people that he cares deeply about have something that he feels is impossible for him to achieve. He thought he found that in both Jon and Dany, as all three of them, as Dinklage pointed out, share the status of being outsiders, of wanting to make the world better than they found it. But now Jon and Dany getting together has changed the dynamic, and it’s a bit of a parallel with Jaime and Cersei. No matter how much Jaime loved Tyrion, he was always going to love Cersei more, and Tyrion is left as a third wheel, of sorts. And what does this mean for Jon and Dany and their survival if all of Tyrion’s models for romantic love ended in tragedy?

So yes, I do think there is romantic jealousy in there, but like Dinklage said, it’s complicated. And it’s not necessarily a new feeling for Tyrion but a symptom of what he’s always struggled with.

summary: I briefly discussed this yesterday with @puresummermagic and it’s been a topic I’ve been thinking about for awhile. I personally...
body:
Will Cersei Make A Play For Winterfell? You Bet Your Ass She Will!

I briefly discussed this yesterday with @puresummermagic and it’s been a topic I’ve been thinking about for awhile. I personally believe that Cersei will absolutely make a play for Winterfell. I’m willing to bet money on it! Why you ask? Well because essentially the two smartest players in the game brought up the importance of not ignoring/forgetting Cersei and 100% imply that she will make a play! Sansa and Littlefinger were the only people who were taking the Cersei threat seriously and are not underestimating her at all!

In the scene above here’s the most important parts of Jon and Sansa’s dialogue:

Sansa:”You’ve been so consumed with the enemy in the North you’ve forgotten about the one to the south.”

Sansa: “We still have a wall between us and the Night King there’s nothing between us and Cersei.”

Jon: “There’s a thousand miles between us and Cersei. Winter is here the Lannister’s are a southern army. They’ll NEVER range this far North.”

Sansa: “You’re the military man but I KNOW HER. If your her enemy, She’ll Never Stop until she’s destroyed you. Everyone who’s ever crossed her she’s found a way to murder!”

Y’all this entire dialogue is so important! It wasn’t just filler for the show. There’s one important point I want to bring up about this scene. I love that fact that Sansa makes it explicitly clear to Jon that she knows Cersei. She is fully aware of who they’re enemy is and what she’s capable of. Apart from the stories Jon’s heard and the atrocities Cersei has brought upon his family, he doesn’t know shit about Cersei! He hasn’t had firsthand experience of her cruelty and shouldn’t assume that he knows what she’s capable of or whether or not she’s a viable threat because of winter. Honestly that’s silly.

For some reason this scene makes me think of Olenna’s words to Jaimie here:

In this scene Olenna says:

“Whatever I imagined necessary for House Tyrell I did, but your sister has done things I wasn’t capabale of imagining. That was my prized mistake a failure of imagination!”

This is the enemy that Jon and Sansa are dealing with. This is what Jon fails to understand. This is a person who is capable of doing things that even some of the smartest game players couldn’t even fathom. Olenna’s words also reminds me of this scene:

Littlefinger mentions that the northerners are solely focused on the threat beyond the wall.

Sansa: “As they should be.”

Littlefinger:”I know Cersei better than anyone here. If you turn your back on her……”

Y’all, the show is making it perfectly clear that Cersei is a threat that should equally be taken as seriously as the Night King. Make no mistake, Sansa absolutely agrees with Littlefingers assessment of the situation. She’s already ahead of the game which is why she broached this same topic with Jon in the first episode of the season. But of course, she’s not going to openly agree with Littlefinger and let him know her thoughts. She’s going to continue to do her part to prepare her people for the long night.

Anyway back to the meta!

After Sansa states that she’s fully aware of how dangerous Cersei is Littlefinger’s response is this:

“Fight every battle everywhere always in your mind. Everyone is your enemy, everyone is your friend. Every possible series of events is happening all at once; Live that way and nothing will surprise you! Everything that happens will be something that you’ve seen before! “

I think this is foreshadowing of Game of Thrones in general but I also think this is foreshadowing particularly pertaining to Cersei. I mean how can it not be! This was the piece of advice Littlefinger gave Sansa after discussing Cersei! Also this definitely makes Olenna’s words come to life.

Where Olenna failed was that she couldn’t think about the endless POSSIBILITIES that Cersei could see to her families demise. Her imagination wasn’t big enough. Will Cersei Make A Play For Winterfell? You Bet Your Ass She Will!

I briefly discussed this yesterday with @puresummermagic and it’s been a topic I’ve been thinking about for awhile. I personally believe that Cersei will absolutely make a play for Winterfell. I’m willing to bet money on it! Why you ask? Well because essentially the two smartest players in the game brought up the importance of not ignoring/forgetting Cersei and 100% imply that she will make a play! Sansa and Littlefinger were the only people who were taking the Cersei threat seriously and are not underestimating her at all!

In the scene above here’s the most important parts of Jon and Sansa’s dialogue:

Sansa:”You’ve been so consumed with the enemy in the North you’ve forgotten about the one to the south.”

Sansa: “We still have a wall between us and the Night King there’s nothing between us and Cersei.”

Jon: “There’s a thousand miles between us and Cersei. Winter is here the Lannister’s are a southern army. They’ll NEVER range this far North.”

Sansa: “You’re the military man but I KNOW HER. If your her enemy, She’ll Never Stop until she’s destroyed you. Everyone who’s ever crossed her she’s found a way to murder!”

Y’all this entire dialogue is so important! It wasn’t just filler for the show. There’s one important point I want to bring up about this scene. I love that fact that Sansa makes it explicitly clear to Jon that she knows Cersei. She is fully aware of who they’re enemy is and what she’s capable of. Apart from the stories Jon’s heard and the atrocities Cersei has brought upon his family, he doesn’t know shit about Cersei! He hasn’t had firsthand experience of her cruelty and shouldn’t assume that he knows what she’s capable of or whether or not she’s a viable threat because of winter. Honestly that’s silly.

For some reason this scene makes me think of Olenna’s words to Jaimie here:

In this scene Olenna says:

“Whatever I imagined necessary for House Tyrell I did, but your sister has done things I wasn’t capabale of imagining. That was my prized mistake a failure of imagination!”

This is the enemy that Jon and Sansa are dealing with. This is what Jon fails to understand. This is a person who is capable of doing things that even some of the smartest game players couldn’t even fathom. Olenna’s words also reminds me of this scene:

Littlefinger mentions that the northerners are solely focused on the threat beyond the wall.

Sansa: “As they should be.”

Littlefinger:”I know Cersei better than anyone here. If you turn your back on her……”

Y’all, the show is making it perfectly clear that Cersei is a threat that should equally be taken as seriously as the Night King. Make no mistake, Sansa absolutely agrees with Littlefingers assessment of the situation. She’s already ahead of the game which is why she broached this same topic with Jon in the first episode of the season. But of course, she’s not going to openly agree with Littlefinger and let him know her thoughts. She’s going to continue to do her part to prepare her people for the long night.

Anyway back to the meta!

After Sansa states that she’s fully aware of how dangerous Cersei is Littlefinger’s response is this:

“Fight every battle everywhere always in your mind. Everyone is your enemy, everyone is your friend. Every possible series of events is happening all at once; Live that way and nothing will surprise you! Everything that happens will be something that you’ve seen before! “

I think this is foreshadowing of Game of Thrones in general but I also think this is foreshadowing particularly pertaining to Cersei. I mean how can it not be! This was the piece of advice Littlefinger gave Sansa after discussing Cersei! Also this definitely makes Olenna’s words come to life.

Where Olenna failed was that she couldn’t think about the endless POSSIBILITIES that Cersei could see to her families demise. Her imagination wasn’t big enough. Essentially what Littlefinger is telling Sansa here is that she needs to always stretch the boundaries of her imagination. She needs to always think about every possibility certain situations can play out so that she can never be caught off guard.

Cersei has absolutely no problem in this department. This is the same women who stays up all night thinking about ways she can get her revenge/kill her enemies. Her imagination knows no boundaries and she’s down to do whatever is necessary to accomplish her goals.

That’s why I believe without a doubt that Cersei is going make a play for Winterfell! Winter or not if she wants to do something she’s going to do it! I can totally see Cersei attacking Winterfell as the Night King is attacking Winterfell, I can see her kidnapping Sansa, I can see her doing a lot of crazy shit! The point is Cersei is not going to sit on the Iron Throne and wait for her enemies to arrive at her doorstep! She always has a game going on behind the scenes and I fully expect for her to pull out her biggest tricks in the last season.

blog.title: lead me to the light
blog.description: on a hiatus : non-fandom blog here: demelzawatt.tumblr.com

summary: Tonight I specifically want to talk about Peter Dinklage’s new interview that has some fans latching onto this idea that Tyrion...
body:
Tonight I specifically want to talk about Peter Dinklage’s new interview that has some fans latching onto this idea that Tyrion is in love with Dany.

Let’s get ready boys and girls….. you know how lengthy these posts get with me ;)

“[I]t’s complicated,” Dinklage admitted to Entertainment Weekly. “A lot of the time with Tyrion, it’s professional and personal. Obviously, he has feelings for Daenerys. He loves her — or thinks he does. She’s awe-inspiring. He’s questioning that because he doesn’t have a good track record for falling in love. There’s jealousy wrapped up in there.”

“[Tyrion] loves Jon Snow, too. They’re the two people he has the most in common with, in a way — they’re both outsiders in their own families who have refused to follow the path their family has taken, and hopefully for the better. He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because passion and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.”

Before we dive in, I want to remind everyone that in the seasons past Sophie Turner has frequently labeled Sansa in ways that DO NOT show up in the series itself.  I can’t find articles for the exact lines I’m thinking of, but it was nearly always an inference to Sansa being darker, of having control, and such like that.

We never really see what Sophie is describing… but it doesn’t stop it from being a notation for her character’s motivation!  However in the script for 707, there is a point where Sansa is described - in script notation - being exactly what Sophie described her as in an interview.

Which made me realize, and reminded me, that quite often in screenplays character motivation for any specific scene exists…. but they are not always the “final canon” in what we see play out on our screens (especially when said notation is for a single episode, and we never had any build up to this rare character action that seems a little out of place given, ya know, we didn’t see anything to suggest they would to X or Y).

So from there, let’s take us back to a few tidbits from Peter Dinklage’s interview above….

“A lot of the time with Tyrion, it’s professional and personal. Obviously, he has feelings for Daenerys. He loves her — or thinks he does. She’s awe-inspiring. He’s questioning that because he doesn’t have a good track record for falling in love. There’s jealousy wrapped up in there.”

Bear in mind that previously Peter has indicated Tyrion’s feelings towards Dany, but CANONICALLY we have never SEEN that play out on screen.  Which means that Peter has obviously seen script notations about this ‘love’—-though it is clearly a nondescript because there has never been anything in dialogue to indicate any kind of romantic love (such as how explicit Jorah’s love for Dany has been shown, or the very blatant attraction that Jon had for Dany).  I think this ‘love’ Tyrion feels is an adoration, built out of respect… and I think the jealousy has nothing to do with ‘romantic love’, but everything to do with the PROFESSIONAL alliance with Dany…. given some of the moments in the past season (7) I came away feeling very strongly that Tyrion is feeling slighted professionally.  He no longer has Dany’s ear as her 2IC that he once did, Jon has taken that place…. given that he’s very likely to be her soon-to-be King (or perhaps that’s at least that’s how Tyrion sees it).

“[Tyrion] loves Jon Snow, too. They’re the two people he has the most in common with, in a way — they’re both outsiders in their own families who have refused to follow the path their family has taken, and hopefully for the better. He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because passion and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.”

Right here, it’s very evidently shown that this is about the PROFESSIONAL alliance that Tyrion has with Dany; he loves Tyrion and Dany with equal adoration and respect, they have been outsiders just as he himself has been so he feels this very big bond to them, and he is CONCERNED about what Jon and Dany being together romantically will do for the greater good of Westeros.

This is nothing to do with romantic love.  It’s platonic love, an adoration born out of respect and kinship, as stated above.

(And I’ll be totally honest, the ‘Tyrion is a secret Targaryen’ side of me is feeling like the trio feel a familial link towards one another, however I get shot down for that opinion so I won’t go any further with it lol)

With that in mind…. let’s also look towards Sophie’s latest interview with the same kind of perspective as we did the above, because I can’t talk about Peter’s interview without also bringing up this gem in discussion.

“She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge. It’s the first time you ever see her like that, and it’s so amazing to see her like that – kind of owning her destiny,” says Sophie. “She has Littlefinger, Cersei, Margaery, everyone’s wisdom and teachings all behind her…She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge.”

What do I get from this?  That Sophie was instructed to play Sansa, in the opening of season eight, as being very protective of those within the walls of Winterfell, and feeling empowered because she is in charge of the castle.  She will exude confidence and strength because she feels as though, finally, after all she has been through, her destiny is finally hers to command.

Going on the trailer tidbit (Jon and Sansa reuniting), I believe that Sansa’s power will be taken from her upon Jon and Dany’s arrival in Winterfell.  I’m hoping that will mean it will drive her protectiveness even further (especially since that was such a prominent character arc point in Sophie’s interview).  She’ll likely disagree with their plans and how they mean to execute them.  No doubt she will want to be the last woman standing in Winterfell as it falls (I think Tyrion, and/or Brienne, will encourage her to leave shortly before Winterfell falls though).


The 707 script link: http://www.emmys.com/sites/default/files/collateral/118%20Game%20Of%20Thrones%20-%20The%20Dragon%20and%20the%20Wolf.pdf

Just my couple dollars worth of theories and viewpoints in regards to the season 8 interview tidbits so far.

How about you guys?

Bear in mind that previously Peter has indicated Tyrion’s feelings towards Dany, but CANONICALLY we have never SEEN that play out on screen.  Which means that Peter has obviously seen script notations about this ‘love’—-though it is clearly a nondescript because there has never been anything in dialogue to indicate any kind of romantic love (such as how explicit Jorah’s love for Dany has been shown, or the very blatant attraction that Jon had for Dany).  I think this ‘love’ Tyrion feels is an adoration, built out of respect… and I think the jealousy has nothing to do with ‘romantic love’, but everything to do with the PROFESSIONAL alliance with Dany…. given some of the moments in the past season (7) I came away feeling very strongly that Tyrion is feeling slighted professionally.  He no longer has Dany’s ear as her 2IC that he once did, Jon has taken that place…. given that he’s very likely to be her soon-to-be King (or perhaps that’s at least that’s how Tyrion sees it).

“[Tyrion] loves Jon Snow, too. They’re the two people he has the most in common with, in a way — they’re both outsiders in their own families who have refused to follow the path their family has taken, and hopefully for the better. He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because passion and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.”

Right here, it’s very evidently shown that this is about the PROFESSIONAL alliance that Tyrion has with Dany; he loves Tyrion and Dany with equal adoration and respect, they have been outsiders just as he himself has been so he feels this very big bond to them, and he is CONCERNED about what Jon and Dany being together romantically will do for the greater good of Westeros.

This is nothing to do with romantic love.  It’s platonic love, an adoration born out of respect and kinship, as stated above.

(And I’ll be totally honest, the ‘Tyrion is a secret Targaryen’ side of me is feeling like the trio feel a familial link towards one another, however I get shot down for that opinion so I won’t go any further with it lol)

With that in mind…. let’s also look towards Sophie’s latest interview with the same kind of perspective as we did the above, because I can’t talk about Peter’s interview without also bringing up this gem in discussion.

“She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge. It’s the first time you ever see her like that, and it’s so amazing to see her like that – kind of owning her destiny,” says Sophie. “She has Littlefinger, Cersei, Margaery, everyone’s wisdom and teachings all behind her…She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge.”

What do I get from this?  That Sophie was instructed to play Sansa, in the opening of season eight, as being very protective of those within the walls of Winterfell, and feeling empowered because she is in charge of the castle.  She will exude confidence and strength because she feels as though, finally, after all she has been through, her destiny is finally hers to command.

Going on the trailer tidbit (Jon and Sansa reuniting), I believe that Sansa’s power will be taken from her upon Jon and Dany’s arrival in Winterfell.  I’m hoping that will mean it will drive her protectiveness even further (especially since that was such a prominent character arc point in Sophie’s interview).  She’ll likely disagree with their plans and how they mean to execute them.  No doubt she will want to be the last woman standing in Winterfell as it falls (I think Tyrion, and/or Brienne, will encourage her to leave shortly before Winterfell falls though).


The 707 script link: http://www.emmys.com/sites/default/files/collateral/118%20Game%20Of%20Thrones%20-%20The%20Dragon%20and%20the%20Wolf.pdf

Just my couple dollars worth of theories and viewpoints in regards to the season 8 interview tidbits so far.

How about you guys?

Let’s get ready boys and girls….. you know how lengthy these posts get with me ;)

He loves her — or thinks he does. She’s awe-inspiring. He’s questioning that because he doesn’t have a good track record for falling in love. There’s jealousy wrapped up in there.”

“[Tyrion] loves Jon Snow, too. They’re the two people he has the most in common with, in a way — they’re both outsiders in their own families who have refused to follow the path their family has taken, and hopefully for the better. He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because passion and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.”

We never really see what Sophie is describing… but it doesn’t stop it from being a notation for her character’s motivation!  However in the script for 707, there is a point where Sansa is described - in script notation - being exactly what Sophie described her as in an interview.

Which made me realize, and reminded me, that quite often in screenplays character motivation for any specific scene exists…. but they are not always the “final canon” in what we see play out on our screens (especially when said notation is for a single episode, and we never had any build up to this rare character action that seems a little out of place given, ya know, we didn’t see anything to suggest they would to X or Y).

title: Shadow-ish 14 Teaser
body:
*pokes head in*

I’m writing! I’m writing! I know it’s been eons since the last update, but new job and all that is kicking my butt right now. :(

But here’s just a little snippet of what’s going on. Keeping fingers crossed for an update next week at the latest. Thanks for being so patient! (((hugs)))

Jon’s smile was bitter. “I came to King’s Landing with a little more than a hundred gold dragons and not much else. If I end up losing everything, that’s okay. I’ll just go back to construction and earn my living the hard way. I’m not averse to getting these hands dirty you know.”

“Urgh. Stop being so perfect. You’re sickening,” Missandei retorted with a roll of her eyes, though they did widen at the sudden sensation of his warm lips against her cheek. She had to fight back the urge to hit him on reflex.

“Thank you,” Jon said with such quiet intensity, she could feel an unwanted flood of heat race through her until her cheeks felt like they were literally burning. Goodness, now she could truly understand why Dany was so smitten by him. Anyone staring into those eyes of stormy grey was likely to drown and never be rescued.

“What are you thanking me for?” she asked, amazed at how calm and collected she sounded.

Jon’s lips curved into a smile. He nodded toward the bedroom he had just left. “For her…for them…” He pointed to the dogs still dozing off in front of the muted television in the living room. “For just being here. I have no idea what Jorah has in store, but knowing you are around …and I guess Davos…will make things a little bit easier for me.” His brows drew together suddenly. “All the same, be careful all right?”

Shadows

title: Son of Ice and Fire
body:
I have been wondering for a while about the decision by D&D to tone down Jon’s ‘specialness’ from what he is in the books. Book Jon is a warg and has prophetic dreams. Show Jon (SJ) is not a warg and although he does have a direwolf, he doesn’t always have him by his side. If he hadn’t returned from the dead, there would be absolutely nothing special about him. This was a decision made very early on in GOT, when GRRM was still very heavily involved, and so must have been done with his blessing. This means that Jon’s warging and dreams will not have a huge impact on the final outcome of the story.

In contrast Daenerys remains super shiny, with dragons and added fireproof-ness. She has gone from strength to strength and she has millions of followers who worship and obey her as a goddess come to earth. This feeds into the fantasy trope of the hero having special powers that are used to defeat the big bad and save the day.

If anything this enforces my belief that the ending to GOT will not be Daenerys being the superhero who will win the day with her dragons and specialness. GRRM is all about turning tropes on their heads.

From the beginning ASOIAF and by extension GOT have been about the limits of power. Having the power to destroy your enemies and burn cities to the ground does not mean you have the ability to rule effectively. If anything, Meereen proves that overwhelming power does not solve social problems and in many cases causes social stagnation due to no one being able to effectively question authority. This is also what happened in Westeros under the Targaryens.

The Targaryens rule by Dragon meant that they never bothered to put in place a system of government that did not rely on fear of the Crown to operate. As Tyrion observed, “Fear is all Cersei has… it makes their power brittle, because everyone beneath them longs to see them dead”. As @wolvesandfoxes25 quoted: “The problem with ruling through fear is that eventually, when the fear fades, fury replaces it.” [Rachel Caine]

So, instead of Daenerys being the 'cure’ to the big bad, I believe she is the opposing big bad. She is the Big Bad Fire, to the Night King being the Big Bad Ice. Both have huge armies and magical abilities. They represent the hard power in the story - power through overwhelming force.

In this scenario, who or what is Jon? He is the everyman. The son of Stark (Ice) and Targaryen (Fire). As the son of Ice and Fire he is in fact neutral. He has no great magical power. His political power is very limited. He makes so many mistakes. His only 'special power’ is very human. He has the ability to mediate between warring factions and to broker peace. He represents soft power in the story - power through the ability to influence and persuade.

Wouldn’t it be refreshing if at the end of GOT, the existential dangers of fire made flesh (dragons) and ice made flesh (white walkers) are defeated, not by magic and special heros, but by people working in co-operation for the greater good. Now THAT would be a good twist.

Wouldn’t it be refreshing if at the end of GOT, the existential dangers of fire made flesh (dragons) and ice made flesh (white walkers) are defeated, not by magic and special heros, but by people working in co-operation for the greater good. Now THAT would be a good twist.
trail.content:
I have been wondering for a while about the decision by D&D to tone down Jon’s ‘specialness’ from what he is in the books. Book Jon is a warg and has prophetic dreams. Show Jon (SJ) is not a warg and although he does have a direwolf, he doesn’t always have him by his side. If he hadn’t returned from the dead, there would be absolutely nothing special about him. This was a decision made very early on in GOT, when GRRM was still very heavily involved, and so must have been done with his blessing. This means that Jon’s warging and dreams will not have a huge impact on the final outcome of the story.

In contrast Daenerys remains super shiny, with dragons and added fireproof-ness. She has gone from strength to strength and she has millions of followers who worship and obey her as a goddess come to earth. This feeds into the fantasy trope of the hero having special powers that are used to defeat the big bad and save the day.

If anything this enforces my belief that the ending to GOT will not be Daenerys being the superhero who will win the day with her dragons and specialness. GRRM is all about turning tropes on their heads.

From the beginning ASOIAF and by extension GOT have been about the limits of power. Having the power to destroy your enemies and burn cities to the ground does not mean you have the ability to rule effectively. If anything, Meereen proves that overwhelming power does not solve social problems and in many cases causes social stagnation due to no one being able to effectively question authority. This is also what happened in Westeros under the Targaryens.

The Targaryens rule by Dragon meant that they never bothered to put in place a system of government that did not rely on fear of the Crown to operate. As Tyrion observed, “Fear is all Cersei has… it makes their power brittle, because everyone beneath them longs to see them dead”. As @wolvesandfoxes25 quoted: “The problem with ruling through fear is that eventually, when the fear fades, fury replaces it.” [Rachel Caine]

So, instead of Daenerys being the 'cure’ to the big bad, I believe she is the opposing big bad. She is the Big Bad Fire, to the Night King being the Big Bad Ice. Both have huge armies and magical abilities. They represent the hard power in the story - power through overwhelming force.

In this scenario, who or what is Jon? He is the everyman. The son of Stark (Ice) and Targaryen (Fire). As the son of Ice and Fire he is in fact neutral. He has no great magical power. His political power is very limited. He makes so many mistakes. His only 'special power’ is very human. He has the ability to mediate between warring factions and to broker peace. He represents soft power in the story - power through the ability to influence and persuade.

Wouldn’t it be refreshing if at the end of GOT, the existential dangers of fire made flesh (dragons) and ice made flesh (white walkers) are defeated, not by magic and special heros, but by people working in co-operation for the greater good. Now THAT would be a good twist.

summary: Tyrion the villain and what it means for Jonsa
title: Tyrion the villain and what it means for Jonsa
body:
Because the Jonsa fandom is literally the brightest and best, I had to look up on GRRM saying that Tyrion is a villain. Lo and behold, there were so many threads about it.

Read this interesting piece on Reddit with my shipper goggles in FULL force:


This one reddit user said this about the outline, but I think he/she didn’t hit the mark on which STARK. Reddit user thinks it’ll be Dany, and it could be a possibility, but what if it’s Sansa? Why would the MAJOR change be from Arya to Dany? I think GRRM already made Dany before he thought up of Sansa, so it wouldn’t make sense??

Tinfoil hat on: GRRM changed it from Arya to Sansa. I mean, come on. We get Tyrion asking about Sansa to Jon. What Tyrion wasn’t expecting was the Bat Glare from Jon while he was talking asking about his “wife”. Tyrion still used that word, you guys! We know the man is a little bitter (in the books someone mentioned) about Sansa leaving him in King’s Landing. I don’t think his feelings for Sansa are intense but…

 Unfortunately, I do think that Tyrion probably has feelings for Dany- because which man doesn’t at this point in life- and the theory could work if you believe that Jon and Dany are meant to be, but then there’s this other theory about Tyrion helping Cersei kidnap Sansa. That truce that Tyrion made and everyone is wondering what it could be? He could have told Cersei he’d bring Sansa to her. Maybe.

Tyrion doing that………. Will leave a huge wedge between him and Jon.


Tell me your thoughts on it!
